review_body: Awesome book! It came recommended by a friend. I don't usually like sci-fi, but this was stellar. The pace was good, I was invested in the characters, and the ending was conclusive and well done (a difficult feat). I am looking to read more by Neal Stephenson.

review_headline: Great technological futurism for when it was written.
review_body: At the time this book was written and published the technology it prefaced was avantgarde. To read this book over twenty years after it was published is fascinating. His ability to create and describe what would be the internet, viruses and hacker issues, virtual reality, and an a sundry of other technologies is quite amazing. The take on the future of religion, nations, politics, and the public franchising of common and governmental functions is quite interesting and remains to be seen as put into practice. Impressively presented. Than being said, the characters and the story wasn't as fulfilling as the science part of the fiction. Although I am being adamantly encouraged to read a few more of his books I think I will put my reading time to other pursuits. Not to say I won't read anymore from this author, just not a Stephensonian fanatic as some other people I know.
Unusual, one of a kind, cyber punk science fiction, very imaginative.

I don't want to put in any spoilers, but this is a great book.

Pros:
1) It isn't just science fiction. Stephenson weaves in myth, politics, and many themes that are becoming relevant to today's society.
2) Stylistically, the book is really easy to read. While some of the content may not be appropriate, a fifth or sixth grader could understand the prose.
3) It is really fun to see many of Stephenson's ideas about the internet and technology come true in today's world.

Cons:
1) The female characters are a bit underdeveloped and one dimensional
2) Parts can become long and droning or overly pedantic

Overall, it is a great book that I recommend to friends. Like Neuromancer, it is a sci-fi book that non sci-fi fans can appreciate.
fantastic. you like good sci fi? then you buy this book.
One of the best novels by Neal. Nuff' said.

review_headline: Somehow I had missed reading this novel when it first ...
review_body:
Somehow I had missed reading this novel when it first came out in 1992. It is always interesting to read an old Cyberpunk novel and see what the author got right and what he got wrong. In Stephenson’s concept of the near future, privatization has run amuck and governments are weak. Stephenson’s version of the Internet/World Wide Web is called the Metaverse, which has an uncanny resemblance to a web site called “Second Life”.
Some critics believe Snow Crash to be a satire of William Gibson’s Neuromancer, and I think it is a legitimate interpretation. In the opening chapter, one of the main characters, actually called Hiro Protagonist, is delivering pizzas and calling himself the Deliverator. There is also a Jerry Falwell-type character who finances his church by controlling all the fiber optic cable in the world.
On the other hand, Stephenson interrupts the narrative to deliver information critical to understanding the story. He did not have the writing skill to seamlessly insert important information in the text. Furthermore, many of the characters are stereotypes, such as Uncle Enzo, a mafia boss, and other characters, such as Raven, an Aleutian, are motivated by ideologies, not feelings.
Great mix of futuristic, historical, and mythological with a fun sense of humor. Classic Stephenson ;)
Pretty good

review_headline: Not as great as all the hype, but not bad either
review_body:
Unemployed programmer Hiro Protagonist works as a pizza delivery guy in a not too distant future, but it is far enough that the world is a very different place. Big businesses have gotten really big, owning neighborhoods where people are quasi-citizens of the company. They run legitimate businesses like Uncle Enzo's CosaNostra Pizza, Inc., where Hiro works. They also have political connections and, often, organized crime connections as well. The other future development is how the internet has taken off and become a quasi-reality where people have alternate versions of themselves (called avatars) and interact with others who are physically far away. Hiro spends a lot of time in this "metaverse" and has customized several things about his avatar and his "property" in cyberspace. He is a hacker after all. The story hops back and forth between the real world and the computer world.

Things start to change when two things happen. First, on a failed pizza delivery he meets up with Y. T., a fifteen year-old Kourier who delivers messages by skateboarding from sender to receiver. She uses a magnetic harpoon to attach herself to vehicles so she can deliver items swiftly. She becomes an ongoing ally. Second, Hiro's friend Da5id dies when he sees a certain image that makes his mind melt. There's a virus called Snow Crash that's a virtual version of the recreational drug Snow Crash which has become popular but also deadly. Hiro's investigation into the virus catapults him and Y.T. into a fantastic, far-fetched adventure.

The set-up of the book is very interesting. The world is a fascinating imagining of the future, though bits of it are less convincing. Money in the future is highly inflated and some bills are referred to as "Gippers" and "Meeses." That was surely hip and relevant in the early 1990s when the book was written but I doubt Millenials who read this book will have any idea to whom Stephenson is referring. The samegoes for the L. Ron Hubbard character. The story also bogs down in unnecessarily long exposition about ancient Sumerian mythology which is tied into the plot. About half-way through the book I ran out of excitement and energy as a reader. Neither came back as I continued through the rest of the book. The action picks up at the end but my emotional investment in the story was gone so it wasn't as compelling and exciting as it should have been. The book isn't bad, it just isn't as great as the hype around it.
Hilariously poignant and one of my all-time favorites!
great book, highly recommend it, predates the matrix and twice as good.

As with all Stephenson books, this novel proves imaginative and compelling. A well-established futuristic society nestled within the United States is a great setting for an Internet-era showdown among rivaling factions. There is plenty of action and intrigue that builds among the major characters, creating enjoyable narrative tension. Originally published in the 1990s, this novel still projects a possible future that may not be all that far away for us.

review_headline: Maybe my favorite book ever -- and I'm NOT a big reader!
review_body: Some of the most dense writing, ever.  Incredible.  But not for dumb/shallow/clueless people.

review_headline: Writing itself good; intellectual violence behind the plot line bad
review_body:
I am giving this a VERY “split” review. On writing style and the surface level flow of the plot, it’s worthy of five stars.

As for how he develops his plot, specifically, fair chunks of the backbone and background of the plot? It’s three stars at best, maybe only two. I could have considered 3.5 stars overall, but went for three. And now, I'll explain why.

Stephenson does a lot of deliberate violence to some elements of philosophy and religion. And, having read his bio, he’s smart enough to have known better, that’s why I call it deliberate.

The first big thing I noticed in this way? Stephenson gets wrong monistic philosophers. Leibniz and Berkeley immediately jumped to mind as anti-materialist monists, contra his claim that all monistic philosophers are materialists.

Even more wrong is his Procrustrean take on the documentary hypothesis, that is the historical-critical idea that the Torah was created by material from four authors, the Yahwist (J), the Elohist (E), the Deuteronomist (D) and the Priestly author (P), with final editing most commonly presumed to be by someone in the P tradition. His idea that E was that heavily edited by D is iffy at best, and he entirely ignores the P section, which goes back to sacrificial and other Temple cultus prescriptions.

And, I know why he ignores the P section. It entirely undercuts his idea that D was influenced by Sumerian writing and building on the linguistic virus from Sumerian writing that’s the whole cornerstone of the novel. Oops!

But, that’s not all.

Yeah, he was born in Fort Meade; beyond being a college computer luster, maybe his dad worked for the NSA. That’s no excuse for his forced seeing of binaries, as in coding 0 and 1, where they don’t exist.

He also is wrong on tie-ins or riffs on memes and NLP. I’ll cut him slack on memes based on the date of his writing, as they were more scientifically respectable then than now? But NLP? It was known to be pseudoscience 15 years ago.

As for philosophy? If he didn’t knowingly botch monism, then he’s an example of a scientismy type who ought to actually talk to some philosophers.

If other novels of his have as good of writing, or nearly so, and better thought processes and intellectual honesty, I’d be glad to read them. If not, this taste was enough.e then than now? But NLP? It was known to be pseudoscience 15 years ago.

As for philosophy? If he didn’t knowingly botch monism, then he’s an example of a scientismy type who ought to actually talk to some philosophers.

If other novels of his have as good of writing, or nearly so, and better thought processes and intellectual honesty, I’d be glad to read them. If not, this taste was enough.
I found it fast paced and amusing. Intelligent. Book is like 20 years oLd. Seems nit picky to say character depth is lacking.

review_headline: Best cyberpunk book I've ever read
review_body: Best cyberpunk book I've ever read. I actually bought a hardcopy after having borrowed this book from my local library. I read it faster than any other book I've read in the last decade, I was so transfixed. It's a delightful piece of sci-fi and compulsively readable.

This is one of the great cyber punk novels of all time - quite possibly the greatest.  If you haven't yet read it, you are in for an unforgettable treat.  Sublime.  Unforgettable.  This is why we read science fiction.

This is an extremely interesting science fiction simulation of a world in which virtual reality and reality are much more convergent than is actually the case.  Conflict, struggle and gamesmanship of one person against another not only enlightens us concerning this convergence but makes the book interesting as shear fantasy as well.  There is also a fair amount of intellectual discussion among characters that brings out the nature of the simulation.  What can we learn from this?  Just like a simulation in physics or engineering, this is a social physics simulation.  It challenges us to think somewhat more clearly and deeply about computation and the nature of the computer revolution.  I can recommend this book, if one wants to be intellectually alive to some of the technology that is shifting the nature of the social fabric in the modern world.
this book is amazing

review_headline: Snow Crash is still one of the go-to recommendations for modern cyberpunk. But does it fully deserve the hype?
review_body:
Review Originally Posted At: www.FictionForesight.com

Let’s start off easy…Snow Crash is full of awesome concepts: Badass mixed-race sword fighter and hacker Hiro Protagonist? Check. Plucky sidekick girl who skateboards for a living? Check. An ominous antagonist who carries a nuke in the sidecar of his motorcycle? Uh – CHECK. The future US is ran not by the government but by franchises and corporate mafias? Obviously. Fast-paced action inside a shared computer universe called the Metaverse? Yes please. A mysterious computer virus incapacitating the top hackers around the world? You know it.

Stephenson’s third full-length novel brought him to the forefront of science fiction, and it’s easy to see why. In Snow Crash, he showed an uncanny ability to extrapolate actual technologies into very robust, believable, real-world applications. The Metaverse is an interconnected virtual social space, which we see an echo of in today’s social media and MMO gaming. Stephenson also popularized the use of the word “avatar” to describe a virtual body or character. In addition, we see several technologies in the novel that are still coming into popular usage – the skateboarders use something eerily similar to the “Hovding Cyclist Airbag”. Our main character acquires a digital library and a program that is basically Google Earth. And the Snow Crash virus – our main plot point – is, in its most basic form, an internet meme.

The ugly side of all these fantastic things is that there hardly seems room in the book for anything else. Snow Crash is so jam-packed full of amazing ideas that the universe feels somehow incomplete, the characters are two-dimensional at best, and the ending – whew, don’t even get me started. We’ll come back to that in a bit.

The story takes place in a future United States, where the government has become irrelevant and the country marches to the beat of a type of “anarcho-capitalism.” People live in suburban enclaves, run by franchises such as “Mr. Lee’s Greater Hong Kong,” and the American Mafia, who now makes a large profit from delivering pizza. The Los Angeles highways are still lined with lights, but they are patrolled by a private security with easily greased palms, and unless you are sponsored by one of the big businesses you have to fend for yourself.

Life outside the sovereignty of these megacorps is the niche that our protagonists occupy – living in storage containers, hosting underground rock shows, collecting information to sell to any interested parties. Hiro’s life in L.A. is gritty, bright, and feels a little dangerous. However, when he follows the Snow Crash trail to a massive floating raft-city off the coast of Oregon, we suddenly lose all sense of place. It’s understandable that Stephenson doesn't want to bog down the narrative, especially just before the height of the action; but there’s so much he fails to mention that would give our story a setting inside a larger, complete universe. The West Coast doesn't just exist in a cell. I grew up there, and they’d like to think that the rest of the country doesn't exist, but that’s just not true. So where is it? For that matter, how does the rest of the world react to the way Mr. Lee and the Mafiosos are running the U.S.? Couldn't tell you. As it stands, the novel provides just enough explanation to get away with it, but we still feel like our characters are just moving through a space without their feet hitting the ground.

Ah, yes, the characters. Like much of the rest of this work, they sound awesome in concept. But when it comes to creating a fully formed, three-dimensional human being, Stephenson falls short. Hiro Protagonist has little to no back-story, and his motivations for pursuing information regarding the Snow Crash virus are about as imaginative as his name. He wants to sell information about it. Oh, I guess his friend and ex-girlfriend get swept up in the plot and I think maybe Hiro goes to save them, but I don’t remember him seeming to care too much about them. The girl, Y.T., has a mother that the government captured to provide “motivation” for her, but midway through the book she gets swept up in a pointless “romance” with our nuke-toting bad guy, and becomes another damsel for Hiro to rescue. Said bad guy seems to have no real reason to be working for the evil masterminds behind the virus, other than the fact that America wronged his ancestors and his family’s lands, so…obviously America has to go. In theory, these characters have complete back-stories and complex reasons for doing the things they do, but Stephenson fails to deliver – I believe again out of the fear of getting in the way of the story (and the science behind it) itself. So instead of characters we have cardboard cutouts that move through this world simply to get us to the end of the book.

And so, we arrive at the ending. Once we've revealed who is behind Snow Crash and why it is proving so dangerous to hackers around the world, we get to have a happy ending, right? Not particularly. Everyone who can be saved is saved, there’s a sort-of shootout where early benefactors come into play again – and then everyone just goes home. Hiro and Y.T. both remain exactly the same as they have been throughout the story, no learning, or character growth, or any sense of forward progression in their lives. Snow Crash happened to them, and now they presumably just go back to things as they were before. It’s like if the Lord of the Rings had ended with Frodo throwing the ring into the mountain and then just going home. Problem solved, right? Who cares what happened at Minas Tirith?

For all its many shortcomings, Snow Crash is still a novel with a clear vision and where it does excel, it shines. The science behind the Snow Crash virus is interesting and well-researched, and the tech in the world is sowell thought out that even 23 years later, it is still relevant and hardly shows its age. However, the novel as whole reads like it was written by a twenty-something grad student who had a bunch of “wouldn't it be cool if…” ideas and then threw them together into something resembling a story. I think Stephenson had yet to come into his style with this book, so I look forward to reading some of his later works, like Cryptonomicon and Anathem. In my opinion, Snow Crash might be slightly overrated, but has reached a wide audience and has clearly influence today’s technology – I’d say it’s worth your time.

Fun fact: Joe Cornish, director of 2011 feature film Attack the Block, has been signed on by Paramount Studios to write and direct a film adaptation of Snow Crash. Stephenson has warned fans that there’s no guarantee the film will ever be made.

(www.FictionForesight.com)
Love it

review_headline: One of his most memorable works. It's a favorite of mine, and definitely fun to read. I've read it 13 times!
review_body:
Cryptonomicon was the first book of Neal Stephenson’s that I ever read, and it got me started on a long road of fangirling. I was about ten years old. After that, I moved on to Neuromancer, which really got me into the ‘cyberpunk’ genre. Shortly after that, I continued to raid my father’s collection of Stephenson books, and that is when I discovered Snow Crash.
Snow Crash is sort of like The Matrix meets Scott Pilgrim meets Neuromancer. It’s so much lighter, sillier, and amusing than Neuromancer, though. Diamond Age is pretty similar in terms of writing style.
Knowing that Stephenson writes all of his drafts by hand makes him an even more formidable writer when you take into account the amount of detail in his novels. The amount of research he did for all of his books is positively astounding. He also includes humorous tidbits, ranging from subtle to in-your-face funny. Stephenson, for example, named his main character Hiro Protagonist.
The near future is a libertarian paradise. The government intervention is pretty much non-existent; the law enforcement agencies are private and actively compete with one another. This is where Hiro Protagonist comes in. In the beginning of Snow Crash, Hiro almost failed to make a very important pizza delivery to the Mafia. Fortunately for him, a skateboard courier named Y.T. shows up to save him. Her super rad skateboard makes the famous (and ever-coveted) hover-board from Back to the Future look like a broken kid’s bike with sticky training wheels that refuse to turn.
This crazy beginning to the story drives the reader smack into a giant conspiracy. It just gets better. Sword-fights, virtual reality, mind-altering drugs, linguistics, religion, Shumer civilization, mutants, hit-men, atomic-powered Gatling handguns, hackers, and more – This novel has it all.
Snow Crash was written in 1992 and, since then, there have been a lot of books, movies, and television shows that have borrowed some aspect or another from it. All of them failed, however, to truly capture the lightheartedness of the narrative. This book just does not take itself seriously.
The only thing that really annoyed me was the fact that the book is written in present tense. I suppose I could overlook it if there was a reason, but I could not find one. Present tense comes across clumsy and awkward to me, but this may just be my own personal issue. It’s probably not a universal reaction, so I do not take off points for that.
Also, while the character development and progression was great, there wasn’t nearly enough of Raven. He ranks right under Hannibal Lector and the Assassin from Serenity. (Oh, god, the feels.) He is everything a good villain should be: Sexy, intelligent, tempting, and a formidable brute of a nuclear mutant who has a penchant for ripping people to pieces with glass knives.
However, there was plenty of Y.T., the 15-year-old skater chick who saves the world. She is badass and a great role model. She was written with strong personality aspects, and was fun to read. Hiro was…okay. He could have used his Katana a bit more, in my opinion.
Regardless of this little issues, Snow Crash is the paradigmatic Neal Stephenson novel. It grabs the reader right away, thrusts you headlong into this crazy world like you’re going down the line of a Tequila Carshwash. You keep sliding along until you’re left startled, disoriented, and a buzzed when you land at a precipitous ending.
That may sound abrupt, but don’t let that fool you. It absolutely works. Snow Crash is probably (At least in my opinion), one of Stephenson’s most memorable works. It’s certainly a favorite of mine, and it’s definitely a lot of fun to read. Trust me on this – I’ve read it 13 times.

Check out Booklexia for more reviews.or another from it. All of them failed, however, to truly capture the lightheartedness of the narrative. This book just does not take itself seriously.

My all time favorite.

Awful!  I have read some of the other sci fi cyberpunk novels that are popular and really liked them.  This book will have a short interesting scene and characters, and then will have a really long scene that is incredibly boring with long details of history or science.  The book also seems to be a reason to tear down religion whenever it can.  If the author would of stuck to the plot and the characters instead of getting tied up on the side trying to show us how educated and smart he is, with these long diatribes of history or his pseudoscience, the book actually could of been really good. instead it is a complete disaster with every interesting scene never seeming to go anywhere. So if you are a hipster you will probably love this book but if you are not give it a pass.

I chose this book from a Top 25 type list. Knew nothing about it or the author. The main point I want to emphasize is that this Cyberpunk genre is not Sci-Fi like what I think of when I think Sci-Fi (I think now they label it "hard"). Anyway, if you enjoy interstellar travel, planets, moons, aliens, robots, and other technology, don't look here. Snow Crash all takes place in LA in the not-too-distant future. Personally, I can't understand why it is even classified as Sci-Fi except that it includes virtual reality, teleportation, and cyberhackers.

That said, it was fun reading it. The author has a sense of humor naming his main character "Hiro Protagonist". Generally, the story keeps moving even though as other readers have noted he may have overdone the Sumerian mythology thing. So, on the one hand, this book is light enough to make it a beach read, however, certain 5 star posts which state things like "this is the best book I've read in my life" are going way too far folks! One even compared this author to Tolkien. Wow, I'm not sure what these people read! Bottom line: overall entertaining; but not great literature. This cyberpunk thing, I'm not sure if I like it or not right now.
This is my favorite cyberpunk book.

review_headline: Totally weird - but in a good way
review_body:
I think this was the weirdest book I've ever read.

I mean that mostly in a good way. The cynical/sarcastic/satirical style of writing made me laugh out loud on several occasions, and it just made for a fun read overall. I'm one of those people who is easily entertained by certain styles of wording, and this book didn't disappoint on that front. The setup and worldbuilding were almost a joke, but it was a joke that might turn into reality one of these days - who knows. The concept of the Metaverse was really interesting, especially considering the book was written when our modern internet was just coming into existence.

It was also weird in a not-as-good way, hence the 4 star rating. I've never been much of a fan of mythology in the first place, and the fact that it was all woven into a cyberpunk story about hackers and computer viruses didn't do a lot for me. It reminded me of the First Civilization characters from Assassin's Creed and I've always thought they were really annoying.

I probably would have never picked this book up if I just found it on a shelf somewhere so I'm glad I was forced to read it for a lit class. I totally would have missed out.

And what is it about mafia dons always being such awesome, badass characters? This is like the 3rd thing I've read/watched/written lately starring a really cool mobster character.

review_body: A classic, nice new edition.

review_headline: add to the fun of reading the story
review_body:
_Snow Crash_ is a tour de force of a sci-fi cyberpunk novel, filled with intricate plot twists. Stephenson's research of ancient Mesopotamian myths and religions, and of Sumer and its language in particular, may put Dan Brown's The Da Vinci Code to shame. As the wild plot unfolds on a future dystopian Earth, the author introduces one after another deus ex machina to rescue the day -- all to the odd effect of making such a plot mechanism seem plausible through repetition.

_Snow Crash_ seems to describe the world that might emerge if today's far right corporatists and those who yearn for a libertarian future where all government is a thing of the past and the most ruthless war lords rule massive global monopolies and all compete with one another intent on taking everything for themselves. As such, it is both an alien world and one you will recognize immediately in the politics of today. A chilling look at what might be, and a totally thrilling story to expound it. And Stephenson's imaginings or future pizza delivery, a courier service that skateboards freeways via cables the thrashers magna-poon onto autobahn speed automobiles, etc. add to the fun of reading the story.

On the downside; reason and rationality, which seem to be on the rise today; lose to blind faith in the most absurd of beliefs. Magic controls reality. The most unimaginably unlikely coincidences are the rule, not the exception. And there are all those deus ex machinas that the convoluted plot could not survive without. It's fascinating reading, lots of subtle humor and puns. But the plot would serve as fuel for Douglas Adam's infinite improbability drive. In the end, that dropped the book from the 5 I thought it would be when I began reading to the three I ended up giving it.

Review originally published by Goodreads, https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1230819459

Talk about a great novel! Oculus rift anyone?

review_headline: and the whole idea and plot were not fun to follow
review_body: This book is not for everyone.  I can acknowledge that the author is very creative and clever, but I could not make myself finish this book.  I dreaded picking it up and trying to read more of it.  The world the author created is just downright weird, and the whole idea and plot were not fun to follow.  I really wanted to enjoy it because I know it's considered to be a great sci-fi book, but it just wasn't my cup of tea.
This is one that I read at least once a year

review_headline: One of my favorite books ever!
review_body: One of my favorite books ever!
Gift for a relative.

review_headline: It's worth the read if you were interested in it from its reputation.
review_body: Such a great, unexpected beginning, funny, and interesting with the world building. Given that it was made in 1992 or something, it was fun to identify the predictions that panned out and those that didn't. Then comes the awful middle, with tons of boring, unrealistic exposition. At the end, sort of recovers-lots of fast paced action, but says to hell with the sub plot resolutions and character building. Overall, enjoyable but didn't live up to the beginning. It's worth the read if you were interested in it from its reputation.
Thanks so much - great deal + perfect shipping and condition! AAAAAAAA++++

review_headline: Unique Take on Future Tech and Society
review_body: I don't share the complete awe that many reviewers hold for this book, but I have to say it's fresh (for a 1990 offering), thoughtful, fun, and stimulating. The author has done a great job of projecting technology trends that are actually true now, as well as offering some satirical and hilarious twists. The central conceit, that the brain is hard-wired for language and can be "infected" by a "virus" made of language, is fascinating. If you are a fan of computers and/or the future, check it out.
fast ship. Great read.

review_headline: Reader is really good. Has lots of convincing voices for the different ...
review_body:
Reader is really good. Has lots of convincing voices for the different characters.
Story is entertaining. Excellent prediction of the future. Started listening to it because of a high recommendation from a Computer Science professor.

I give it only four stars because it has lots of F-bombs.

review_headline: Not just dated, but lousy futurology to boot
review_body:
Before buying this book, take note of the date on which it was published: 1992

Even back then I would have taken issue with its lousy futurology, like science fiction set centuries into the future with computer keyboards.

For example, I would have noted all the references to a future filled with videotape when laserdiscs were ubiquitous in 1992. Okay, laserdiscs went the way of the Sony Betamax, but they were a clear pointer to a future filled first with CDs and then DVDs and then downloadable computer files, and in the near future wearable interfaces that will give us our entertainment in holography indistinguishable from real life (a technology I saw demonstrated in the Japanese Pavilion at Expo 88 in Brisbane in 1988, minus the bit about being indistinguishable from real life and the bit about the wearable interface).

As I wrote back in the last millennium when video files in stuttervision became ubiquitous on all forms of data storage, "the written word is dead – we just haven't woken up to it yet" (and that was before cameras became ubiquitous on mobile phones, indeed before mobile phones became ubiquitous).

This is from Stephenson's steampunk period (and if you don't know what "steampunk" is, I refer you to an Australian reviewer of Stieg Larsson's "The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo" who described the eponymous heroine as a "steampunk Pippi Longstocking"), and he is not completely unintelligent about the way his dystopian future might develop from our present, so the book is not without its interests for today even if it does look more-than-somewhat dated.

And it's possibly worth reading for its thinly-disguised satire of Scientology and its founder L. Ron Hubbard alone!

This is the first Neal Stephenson book that I've read, having ordered it due to recommendations online, and I was very pleased with it. It starts right off the bat with a lot of action and you are immediately thrown into a new age where pizza delivery is one of the most important jobs. Well, as you can predict, Hiro is given a pizza with very little time left to make the delivery. My favorite part about the book is how indepth the author goes into the history of the world, and how certain things happening came to be.

This book is ultra-fast paced. Reading it is like taking a hit of crystal meth then watching Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Die Hard, and the History Channel at the same time--on fast forward.

Snow Crash is highly versatile adventure. At some parts it felt as if I were reading a novelization of Saturday morning cartoons from the '90s, before it metamorphosed into some Aldous Huxley brain busting material. Finally, a liberal dose of head slicing, rocket launching, machine gun blasting, and getaway action.

This book is 100% politically incorrect. It guts every culture for a comic book effect. In Stephenson's future, we exist as extreme stereotypes for survival the same way prison gangs separate races. At first this pissed me off, but I now enjoy his sacrilegious view of everything. The future has been thoroughly violated by the corporate-criminal mindset.

I highly recommend this book, but I would not like to repeat that kind of reading experience for a while. The non-stop information overload left me plenty crispy. I suspect that Stephenson "programmed" Snow Crash (the novel) to infect the user. Those who've already read it know what I mean.

"Look. Your brain has an immune system, just like your body. The more you use it--the more viruses you get exposed to--the better your immune system becomes. And I've got a hell of an immune system. Remember, I was an atheist for a while, and then I came back to religion the hard way."
Good smart story, liked the characters and the Tron-like premise, the ending was a little dicey but overall a good read

review_headline: Favorite first chapter of a book ever
review_body: Favorite first chapter of a book ever.  Like cyberpunk that provokes questions about our very nature as human beings?  Read this.
Great book.
As expected, and quick turn around.  Thank you.
Great read!
Looking forward to my next Stephenson read, enjoyed every page and character.  Thanks Neal!
The most stunning novel I'd read at that time. It just knocked me out!
I own this book

review_headline: A Mistaken View of the Future, A Disappointing Plot
review_body:
By now (2014), this is a retro-futuristic tale that we can see completely missed the mark. Published in 1992, Stephenson's view of the future was entirely wrong. 1992 was before the web, or at least before the web became mainstream. And it isn't foreseen by Stephenson - instead there is a virtual reality world called the Metaverse, in which distance still plays a role. Imagine if you went online and still had to travel for 10 minutes to get from Target.com to Amazon.com. Or if you wanted to see a show but still could get bad seats where you couldn't see it well. If someone wanted to communicate with someone not next to them in the Metaverse, they'd have to go offline and take a phone call. It all seems silly in 2014.

The collapse of government, the rise of communities and an entirely new way of life ruled by immense corporations - I can see where he got this idea, but these things would take hundreds of years to happen. So was the development of the net that slow? Or the social changes supposedly that fast?

The part about the Tower of Babel - now this was what got me interested in the book. It had some really great ideas on the origin of language, and I wanted to see where this was going. Combine it with the changes in the world and the Metaverse and you have some really interesting possibilities. I kept waiting and waiting to see what would be developed, but Stephenson didn't really do anything interesting with it. In fact, while it proved to be an important element, the entire reason for Snow Crash to exist (and thus this book) is based on a misunderstanding of programmers and the companies they work for.

When it is revealed why the antagonist(s) would go through all this immense trouble, you are left scratching your head. At least, if you are a programmer or understand the tech industry. The "big issue" that drives the story is not even remotely an issue in programming. It isn't today, and it wasn't when this was written.

So as I drew near to the end, I realized that there wasn't going to be any big reveal; that the plot really was just this nonsensical "big issue". It was very disappointing, much like Cryptonomicon. Well-written, with interesting elements and characters, but the big picture left you very unsatisfied.

I've read 6 Neal Stephenson novels and enjoyed them all immensely, but this is an unmitigated disaster. There are numerous very basic structural problems that render it completely nonsensical.

- Characters are literally in two places at once in some scenes: i.e. Hiro rescuing Y.T. in one part of the city, and being in his storage unit logged into the metaverse at the same time.

- Other characters have entire arcs set up only to never be paid off: i.e. Y.T.'s relationship with Uncle Enzo.

- Plot devices aren't even paid off: i.e. Raven's nuclear bomb.

- In the middle of major action sequences there are huge gaps in time: i.e. Hiro finally gets to the raft only to spend weeks (?) floating in the ocean waiting to be rescued? Or he finally makes it onto the raft, and sits down and plays on his computer for hours while guys with guns are hunting him?

- Massive character leaps occur "off screen": i.e. Hiro all of a sudden goes from a poor nobody to a rich guy with fancy gadgets literally from one scene to the next. And at the end Hiro talks about all the hangouts and meals he and Y.T. have shared and yet in the book they've only ever even met a couple of times and barely know each other.

- There are huge swaths of mostly unimportant dialogue that gets repeated for no reason: pretty much anything to do with the virus.

- Strange conversations take place indicating previous interactions that have never happened: the entire motorcycle conversation between Hiro and Raven for example, which comes out of nowhere, makes no sense, and is totally pointless.

- The end just happens: not only does the ending fail to payoff almost every major and minor character arc, but the finale involves characters that are so secondary to the plot that you couldn't care less about them. They're essentially movie extras, and the main cast isn't even in the vicinity. It would be like if at the end ofStar Wars instead of Luke flying down the Death Star trench with Darth Vader behind him, it was Wedge followed by Grand Moff Tarkin. Think about how crazy that is.

And these are just structural problems. I'm not even taking into account how many grains of salt you would have to take in order to get past the whole ancient Sumerian verbal virus in the first place, or other outlandish jibberish. The number of positive reviews for this are shocking, but even more unbelievable is so few people mentioning these MAJOR plot and character issues. I can get past, and even enjoy, the intentionally cartoonish style. I can get past the intentionally racist stereotypes. I can even get past the absurd sexualization of the 15 year-old and her "sexy" rape scene. I cannot, however, get past the fact that the very basic framework of the book doesn't even make sense.
one of my favorite Stephenson books!
Haven't read it yet.  But the GF loved it.
The Book that inspired The Matrix. Can't hate on that!
This book if fricken hilarious.

review_headline: ... it weren't for HHGTTG this would be my definitive favorite book of all time
review_body: If it weren't for HHGTTG this would be my definitive favorite book of all time. Where that was more philosophical comedy set in space, this is hardcore SciFi to the max. When comparing the Metaverse to the internet we use everyday do keep in mind the copyright. While many of the things depicted in the story still seem a bit over the horizon, though plausible, they were truly far out at the time it debuted. A tight knit world woven of many colorful technological might-well-be's. Though don't come looking for much individual character development, the main character's name is Hiro Protagonist, 'nuff said. The only book to so thoroughly mesmerize my imagination since is a newer work by the author: Anathem. That is an epic feat of world building fascinating in it's vastness as much as it's construction. This is an elegant tapestry of ideas.

review_headline: Audio quality was just fine -- I listened in my car
review_body: I own several copies of this books, the unabridged audio tapes and it was completely worth it to upgrade my yearly re-listen by buying the CDs. Audio quality was just fine -- I listened in my car.
Amazing book if you like pizza, and ninjas!

review_headline: Mr. Stephenson, where have you been most of my life?
review_body:
Holy moly!!! The last \\"thick novels\\" I read were Hitchhiker's Guide and Dirk Gently books from the late, great Douglas Adams (in the mid- to late '80s), but when a friend recommended Snow Crash and I started reading it on a recent road trip, I was blown away by:

a) Stephenson's sense of humor and wordplay (who could resist a main character named Hiro Protagonist?),

b) the fun of keeping in mind that the book was published in 1992 -- BEFORE the advent of the World Wide Web (which hit as I went off to get a bachelor's in Mathematical and Computer Sciences at the Colorado School of Mines),

c) just how entertaining Stephenson's unlikely, near-future, cautionary dystopian tale can be!

Also, being a Reconciling (progressive) United Methodist who recently read Rev. Adam Hamilton's wonderful [[ASIN:006223496X Making Sense of the Bible: Rediscovering the Power of Scripture Today]], I really connected with Stephenson's Biblical references and his fascinating foray into Sumerian mythology, etc.

I'm actually only about ⅔ of the way through Snow Crash, but I'm sure I'll love finishing it! (Sheesh, Amazon -- I'm not THAT fast a reader! ;-D)

If you don't mind the foul language, etc. (a faithful movie would definitely be rated R) and you're at least a little nerdy, this is a book for you!

This book was both exciting and interesting. It was a relief to read sci-fi that didn't set up a sequel for a change. I found Stephenson's writing to be exceptional, and was hooked for the majority of the story. Some interesting insights into historical religion as well as potential futures of computer science (although it is funny how many of the things in the book feel extremely obsolete or dated, while others seem impossibly far-off).

I am used to reading space-based sci-fi, but this was definitely a great read. I may even look into reading some of Stephenson's other work in hopes of finding some more one-volume, non-space sci-fi.

review_headline: If you thought Neuromancer gave insight into the possible future...
review_body: So much to love about this book! How can you not love a book that features a hero protagonist named Hiro Protagonist? The description of the book can't capture the true depth and breadth of this book and the future it presents begs so many questions about where we all seem to be heading. My daughter vectored me to this book and I cannot thank her enough! So many times since first reading this book I look at the news headlines and wonder if Stephenson isn't using a crystal ball. It probably doesn't help much to have me say take it on faith and read this book but trying to describe how profoundly I was affected by it is pointless. It's clever, it's funny, it's outrageous, it's cynical, satirical, it's very, very well written! Read the book!

review_headline: Fast paced adventure with some solid characters
review_body:
This is not a bad book at all. It has some very cool parts and some great characters. The story itself isn't bad albeit a bit convoluted but I wish there was a little more explanation about some things such as motives or maybe a little more history on the antagonists. I also really wish there was a better description of the world in which the story takes place. In and of itself, it is awesome. Kind of like a cyberpunk, futuristic, sort of dystopian setting with dashes of nostalgia sprinkled here and there. But there is just no explanation as to why the world is this way or how it came to be so strange and dangerous in such a (seemingly) short time. Another thing that surprised me was the importance that some side characters ended up playing in the more climactic parts. I will say that Hiro and Y.T., the main characters, are both pretty cool and likeable. Some of their actions are admittedly a little over the top and just too cliché but you get the feeling that was the objective in writing the book in this fashion and it actually kind of grew on me as I got further into the story.

Overall, this is a pretty good book. I think it’s definitely a bit overrated and there’s nothing in here that really blew me away or anything. I do like Stephenson’s writing style and it was an easy read. It just never really pulled me in at any point and it was hard to immerse myself in the world created because it was so sporadic and random without explanation. It is one of the harder sci fi’s I have read in the sense that it is pretty complex and very technocentric.

review_headline: Imaginative Sci-Fi with an Interesting Blend of History and Myth
review_body:
In the future, the world has turned into a corporation-dominated landscape in which the United States's economy has become better than everyone else at only two things: entertainment and hyper-speed pizza delivery. Technology rules everything now and has made everything even more efficient (and, as might be predicted, less efficient when talking about the government). Hiro Protagonist (yes, that is his real name) falls victim to this and loses out on a job when he fails to deliver a pizza in thirty minutes or less. Out of a job, he turns to the Metaverse -- an entire world that you can enter through the internet -- where he is one of its initial creators and the most dangerous swordsman around. It is there that a virus called snow crash turns up (something dangerous enough to harm the computer and its user) and Hiro has to find a way to stop it from spreading before its too late.

Neal Stephenson seemed to decide to break most every literary rule (the most egregious of which he ignores is the dreaded "info-dumping"), but his technical writing skills are strong enough and the subject matter is interesting enough that he mostly succeeds. In fact, right from the opening pages is nothing but discussing the futuristic world he has created. He does this a lot: how pizza delivery works, the typical workday of a governmental employee, the mechanics of a guard dog that is more machine than flesh, the creation and adoption of different languages and how they relate to Sumerian myth and culture, etc. But there is a sense of humor that is funny enough and a way he teaches the reader that it does not hamper the story too much.

As characters, Protagonist and Y.T. (a spunky teenage Kourier) act as great foils to one another. Hiro has had quite a bit of success in his life, but he still has that stereotypical "nerd" sensibility where he still has some trouble with the female sex. Y.T. is the opposite: she easily understands others but is alwayslooking to ratchet up the excitement in her life. These two work together to solve the Snow Crash mystery, though they never seem to be the best of friends. While there is not much tension between the two of them they still spend more time apart than together. One of the more touching moments in "Snow Crash" is when Y.T. explains to Hiro how he should actually deal with the opposite gender. As one of the villains, Raven is suitably a match in both wits and partial prowess to Hiro. Pretty much every character in the novel seems to evolve from a stereotype of some sort, but it does not ever get in the way enough to make the story less satisfying.

"Snow Crash" suffers from several minor issues, however. There is a giant section of the book that can only be described as a giant info-dump about Sumerian culture. These chapters are interwoven with other sections that are dedicated to scenes that contain more action, but it got to be a bit too much for my taste. As I consider myself one of the more patient readers I know, there will probably be many people who find this to be unforgivable and never finish the book. While it helps in the understanding of the background of the story and is important in the grand scheme of the plot, Stephenson was too heavy-handed in this regard. There is also a scene near the end that reveals a mysterious connection between two characters that simply did not work. The dialogue was forced and the timing was off. The scene would have been better served earlier on when the action was not so chaotic. Finally, there is an abrupt conclusion that simply catches you off guard. It is possible to figure out most of what happens, but Stephenson really needed to include another ten or fifteen pages to help wrap everything up.

There is a sense of irreverence that Stephenson uses during the entirety of the novel that comes across as quite charming. Despite the multitude of deaths and destruction that occurs, it seemslike this is just every day for most of these characters. I'm not sure quite buy Stephenson's premise that language of simply code and we all inherently have the ability to wake up one morning and be able to speak and read Sumerian, binary, French, Sanskrit, Hebrew, or any other of the thousands of languages that are out there in the world. I myself have taken seven years of French and still cannot speak a sentence of it. But the questions he raises concerning language's history are interesting enough to think about (just what did happen during the Tower of Babel sequence?). And while Stephenson made some minor missteps and had a little too much fun in discussing the smaller details, the story is still fun enough and the characters are interesting enough to call "Snow Crash" a success.

4/5
Pretty rad book--glad I read it.
A cyberpunk classic. Good variety, well written. Reads quickly.

review_headline: This is my favorite book. I once met Mr Stephenson at a ...
review_body: This is my favorite book.  I once met Mr Stephenson at a book signing in New York, and he said his favorite work was "The Confusion"  I was a little too star struck at the time to say anything, but you are wrong Neal.  This is your best work.  Maybe you should read it again.

I read Snow Crash after it was recommended by several friends and reading that it was a well-regarded SF novel. It was a shame then that it was nowhere near as enjoyable as I had expected.

Although it was published in 1999 and can therefore be expected to be dated technologically, it was plagued by several other issues. I was especially tired of being beaten over the head by the constant over-sexualization of the character YT. In addition, the unbroken chapters of historical explanation were extremely tedious. Hiro (I appreciate the name joke) is too much of a flawless badass for whom just about everything goes smoothly even when it should not. The characters in general were very difficult to relate to.

I still might recommend the book, but not without some hesitance.
One of the top 5 books I have ever read. Ever.

It's hard to read this 30 year old book without cringing. So much of the plot and context rely on ancient ideas of what \\"the future\\" looks like. And, if you even have the most basic knowledge about programming, you'll recognize so much of what the author feels is \\"hacking\\" just wrong-headed. For example, that they program in binary.

Worse, I feel that a lot of the characters suggest borderline racism (\\"T-Bone Murphy\\" as the name for a black character, for example). Maybe that's ironic? If so, I guess? But the weird context of 80s passions like \\"the Crips\\" just comes across as dated now.

Ultimately, though, the book is just plain boring. Maybe a high school kid in the early 90s would find this book rebellious and amazingly cool... now, though, it's just really bad.

review_headline: Excellent entry into the genre' of "cyberpunk"
review_body: Excellent entry into the genre' of \\"cyberpunk\\", and one of the \\"must-reads\\"of that niche. Buy this for any gamer that likes stories of hacking and covert ops.

review_headline: My second favourite book If you have never picked it up do ...
review_body: My second favourite book If you have never picked it up do yourself a favour and grab a copy. If you into cyberpunk, skateboards and pizza delivery then your in for a treat.

Neal Stephenson writes science fiction that requires a certain level of attention and concentration to follow and stay on top of. You can’t lay a Stephenson novel down for a few days and hope to come back and take up where you left off. This is not pulp science fiction.

In this audacious novel, Stephenson crafts a dystopian Earth near the end of the 20th century. Most civilization has broken down and even in the United States, society has devolved into semi-sovereign “franchulates” (franchise consulates) and “burbclaves” (suburban enclaves). A rampant form of pure capitalism reigns, with private ownership of roads and police protection. Existing alongside this “free for all” is a Metaverse, an on-line world governed largely by hackers. Now, dystopia coupled with virtual reality is nothing new, however Stephenson takes it up a notch, weaving Sumerian and Old Testament mythology throughout the story.

Some may find elements of Stephenson’s world silly, and some of it is pretty far out there, but much of it comes across as biting satire and I found it enormously entertaining. The “heroes” of the story are Hiro Protagonist, a freelance stringer for Central Intelligence Corporation (a privatized successor to the Library of Congress), a computer software designer and the greatest sword fighter in the world (in the Metaverse) and Y.T., a souped up skateboard riding 15 year old courier.

With the help of the Mafia (Cosa Nostra, Inc.) and assorted other supremely interesting characters, Hiro and Y.T. discover a new designer drug, Snow Crash, whose purpose is to inject a virus into the deepest level of the brain, acting much the same as a computer virus. Seeking to prevent spread of the virus, Hiro and Y.T. cross swords with Bob Rife, the richest man on the planet, who seeks to use Snow Crash to exert total control over the world's population. Elements of economic theory, religion, virtual reality, Sumerian mythology and linguistics take this story out of the realm of anything you’ve ever experienced. Four and a half stars, rounded up to five simply on the basis of its originality, scope and audacity.and linguistics take this story out of the realm of anything you’ve ever experienced. Four and a half stars, rounded up to five simply on the basis of its originality, scope and audacity.

After reading and loving Cryptonomicon, I was convinced that I was going to love this book, too! I did really like it, but it just doesn't have the same driving pace that sucked me into Cryptonomicon, and I didn't really start to form an attachment to these characters until very near the end of the book.

Either way, it's still a darn good read, and something that I'd recommend to any of my fellow geeks.

review_headline: Too hip for its own good
review_body: I expect that I'm not in the demographic here (ie older), so all of the super cool language and characters didn't really strike a chord.  Nonetheless, the story was fresh and got on with a good pulse, and the Assyrian (?) backstory was thought provoking.  I'll try again with other works of this author, but I don't think I'll be revisiting this story.
Loved this book, so crazy and fun. In a futuristic world that has taken overpopulation to the next level, the only place anyone wants to be is online in the Metaverse.

review_headline: The second book of his I read
review_body: An incredibly awesome tale, for my money, cooler than Blade Runner (though not by much, respect shall be payed) and worth the read.

review_headline: Noun: The Worst Type of System Crash
review_body:
“Yeah, you know, a monopolist's work is never done. No such thing as a perfect monopoly. Seems like you can never get that last one-tenth of one percent.” – Industrialist L. Bob Rife (Snow Crash)

Neal Stephenson’s “Snow Crash” is a seminal work of Cyberpunk fiction set in a post-collapse America where the government has ceded power and large sections of the country to private interests. Like the Mafia. Yeah, I know dystopian futures with fragmented nations automatically sound extremely bleak, but the joy of this book is regardless of how dark the central themes seem (corporate control, organized crime as government, the rewriting of the human will), the book still manages to have some fun with itself. The early chapters contain a decent amount of profanity (with some more sprinkled around later), but overall the book is teen to adult friendly. There is an interesting cast of characters, a fleshed out virtual world, several subplots that tie up nicely and a fair bit of prescient futurism (This is the book that inspired the Google Earth program). Stephenson put years of research into this novel through a variety of subjects. It stands out as a tent pole title and a great starting point for anyone looking for a slightly lighter variety of his usually ultra-dense prose.

Our main character is a former coder, part-time intelligence agent/sword duelist and currently full-time pizza delivery driver for Cosa Nostra Pizza. His name? Hiro Protagonist. He has a problem. Several in fact:

1. He was just given a pizza that’s about to hit its 30 minute mark. If he can’t get it to the intended destination before the timer expires the current mafia head (Uncle Enzo) will have to fly in from Sicily and personally apologize to the customer. This would mean bad things for Hiro.

2. Something is turning people into easily suggestible vegetables incapable of speaking any modern language. Whatever it is or wherever it’s from, its spreading through both realspace and the Metaverse (their online virtual environment).

3. A giant immigrant fleet with the former United States aircraft carrier Enterprise as its flagship is floating its way to America and everyone on there may already be carriers for the mystery plague.

4. A really large man named Raven leaving destruction in his wake. He may be tied to the source of the previous two problems, but neither Hiro or the authorities can touch him because he has a biologically linked nuclear warhead that he stole from a submarine sitting in his motorcycle sidecar.

"You don't respect those people very much, Y.T., because you're young and arrogant. But I don't respect them much either, because I'm old and wise."
- Uncle Enzo to the “kourier” Y.T., talking about the new generation Mafioso (Snow Crash)

What happens when someone with the power to dominate a diverse populace with secrets from the past runs into an unlikely set of bedfellows who would rather have freedom than uniformity?

This book happens, and it happens to have that magical blend of character, concept, and charisma that makes the unlikely and sometimes unwieldy plot worth the ride.

This and "Diamond age" are, in my opinion, Stephenson's best works. I read Cryptonomicon and got most of the way through the Baroque cycle and didn't even try Anathem, but Snow Crash is one of the best cyperpunk novels since Neuromancer.
This book is extremely entertaining. I love the world that Stephenson creates - not exactly a distopia, but a more realistic chaotic future.

I had to read this for a class, with that said, I read fantasy for fun and enjoy some Sci Fi books. This book starts out as if an angsty teenager were writing it. This doesn't change until the last third of the book. Other than that the way the author describes the future is scary close to what is being developed today.

Not a fan of the writing style.
Well thought out plot.
Interesting way to think of the future.
One of the best and well written books I have ever read. I have read it several times and enjoy it each time.

Interesting book. Very edgy writing--fun, eclectic, fast paced. A bit like how I remember Junot Diez writing. Some language, a single sex scene (kind of hot). Showing its age in a few places, but still a good SciFi adventure.

1. The Metaverse is yet to be realized, but I think will be realized someday. An alternative online universe where anything can be seen or experienced via artificial reality. I think it is 20 years out.

2. There is an amazingly insightful passage about relationships. Hiro is a wandering lost guy, not knowing what he wants to do with his life. He likes this girl and she likes him, but she has left him behind and moved on with her life. YT, Hiro's female sidekick, tells him that he should stop trying to figure his girlfriend out--an impossible task. She tells him that instead he needs to figure out what he wants in life. Once he finds himself, she will go along with the plan because she loves him. But his aimless wandering without a goal/plan/career is untenable for any woman. Know what you want and go for it and if a girl loves you, she will adapt and go along with you. Stagnate and she will leave. I thought there was a lot of truth here.

3. I can't believe this book hasn't been made into a movie yet. Plenty of action scenes and plenty of fans of the book.

4. I learned a bunch about Sumer and it was fun to imagine connections between language and thought. Probably the first novel I have read which used the term "Chomskyan".

5. Even the Mormons got their own enclave state in dystopian Los Angeles. Yeah, someone things we are culturally relevant enough to mention us in their book!

review_headline: Great merchant if you want late delivery
review_body: Beware of the deceptive shipping method they employ. If you want it delivered to your door skip this merchant because you think you're getting UPS but instead you get UPS Surepost which is the the US Postal service. Nothing wrong with that, I suppose, especially if you really like getting your package in 4 days instead of 2, or if you just really like driving yourself to the post office and standing in line while you chat with your neighbors who also used UPS Surepost.

review_headline: One of the co-fathers of cyberpunk
review_body:
Even today few books could fully realize the impact of "The Net" on our lives. With Gibson, Stephenson started it all.
Not only did he make pizza delivery cool, he made hackers even cooler.
I dare you not to read this, then want to frame "The worlds baddest ..."

review_headline: A lot of good parts and one very silly part
review_body:
For all that everyone calls Snow Crash a cyberpunk book, I felt this description is more misleading than helpful. It's true that it's set in a near future (actually now in the past, as of the writing of this review, I believe) that operates by anarcho-corporate principles and it's heavily focused on the notions of hacking and a virtual reality cyberspace, but the tone is totally different. This book has more in common with Umberto Eco than it does with William Gibson, all the way down to the extremely technical discussion of the historical principles underlying the plot and the whimsical tone.

That's not to say I didn't like Snow Crash, as my rating should make clear. The beginning was a laugh a minute, and later on, as the plot got moving, it often kept me turning the pages to see what would happen next. Writing good characters who are easy to understand without giving them too much exposition seems to be a strength for Stephenson, and I liked almost all of the ones he brought to bear here.

However, the underlying conspiracy that unfolds as hero (Hiro) and uncomfortably young sidekick (Y.T.) hunt down the origin of a new drug eponymously called "Snow Crash" becomes more and more difficult to swallow as the pieces mount. I don't want to spoil what all goes into the explanation, but suffice it to say that Stephenson's predilection to mix his fact with his fiction does more harm than good here. I'm the sort of reader who can patiently enjoy long periods of exposition (if well-written), but whenever the author decided it was time to start explaining things, I soon found myself wishing he would get back to the action so I could stop rolling my eyes at such silly stuff.

review_headline: --after that it's just a chase scene.
review_body:
The worst part of this book is the regular returns to the infodumpy core concepts about language and programming and making the analogy between humans in computers. While this would be way better at about half or less the material, and it could have been presented in a more compelling fashion than a conversation, at least Stephenson had the courtesy to break it up narratively with interesting plotty chapters.

The next complaint would be the inexplicable decision to tell portions of the story out of order without adequate context. If this hadn't been done, this would probably be a tighter and more memorable novel. Instead, it's mostly just a long series of shiny bits.

And boy are they shiny. We start with Hiro Protagonist, the last of the freelance hackers and greatest swordfighter in the world. And he delivers pizza for the mafia. Stephenson can write compelling action, but he has the audacity to end a chapter with "--after that it's just a chase scene." The shiny bits make everything worthwhile.

review_headline: I cried for the robo dog
review_body: Snow crash is as strong a cyber thriller as is out there, and is flat out a fun, cool read. somehow, there isn't a movie version yet so read it. But come prepared because it's an involved world and demands your full attention. And it will change your mind forever about how you think about pizza delivery.

review_headline: A Harbinger of Things to Come
review_body:
I have liked all of Neal Stephenson's books. This one is no exception.

It places it's story in the context of a world that has been transformed by the web and instant communication. The story is engaging and fun to follow. It still seems \\"believable\\" even though it was written back at the advent of the \\"web as a fact of life\\".

I love science fiction but have never cared all that much for cyber-stories; space opera is more to my liking. This is an exception. It's fun!
This is a book that would most be enjoyed by computer programmers.  It's definitely a read that gives you an escape from real life.

I really did try to go the distance on this book, but it was just too messy. Some good ideas undermined by poor writing. Stephenson's dystopia has too many discordant elements and the book does not make sense.

I'm still catching up on Neal Stephenson's older works after discovering him with Cryptonomicon a few years ago. Snow Crash is terrific! It was written like 15 years ago before the internet became what it is today, but it's very intriguing and masterfully written. the passage of time has not harmed this classic and it was one of the best 3 books I've read over the past year.

When you read this book, keep in mind that it was published in 1992. The whole virtual reality / second life world is a pure prophecy of a genius. The author introduces imagery and concepts that became a part of engineering culture by now, as much as the Hitchhikers guide. The satire is great, for those who can last through the long nerdy attention to detail. Fortunately, this was one of his first books, it is very concentrated compared to Crypto or Anathema.
Probably NS's best book after Quick Silver.

Reading this book so many years after it was written is enjoyable in more ways than it was meant to.

On top of being a thrilling read, it makes predictions about society and technology in the future. Being in the future already, one can make parallels with said predictions and the world we currently live in and where we seem to be going these days.

review_headline: Hiro Protagonist is a pretty cool guy.
review_body: Despite some obtrusive info dumps, this was a pretty enjoyable read.  The action was descriptive and tense and the characters weren't bad.  I found the villains a lot more interesting than the good guys, though.

review_headline: Read it for Lit class, but awesome either way!
review_body: Although I was required to read Snow Crash for my lit class, it could just as easily have been a "for fun" read, and it got me back into reading sci-fi for fun. The story is centered around the idea that looking at a computer screen displaying a specific pattern of "snow"-like noise can cause the brain to re-write itself, causing the victim to become very sick right away. It is very action-filled but also has deeper commentary on religion and technology. When I actually had a vivid nightmare about seeing a "snow crash" happen on a computer and worrying about getting sick, just like in the book, I knew this would be a 5-star review!

I'm going to keep this short.

I don't like this author's books and here's the quick run down why:

1.) He uses convoluted words for the sake of hearing his own voice. Granted, it wasn't as bad as Diamond Age, but God was it annoying to have to figure out what some of his words meant.

2.) He has an unhealthy obsession with underage girls and wouldn't you know it, one of them is in a sex scene. People say it's supposed to be comedic, but I don't find anything funny about his descriptions of young girls. He also did this in the book Diamond Age with Nell.

3.) The dialogue and word choice is so dated, so 90's. It does not hold up well in this day and age. It's very corny and very campy.

4.) The plot, why do his plots never make any damn sense? It's like he has an idea for a story, write it, forgets what he was writing about, and quickly ties things up at the end.

What was good?

- World building. The guy knows how to build a world and does this marvelously. But world building alone does not a good book make.

- Interestingly, when Hiro talks to the computer librarian. Stephenson's description of how language was passed and history and babylon were terribly fascinating. I could have read the whole book about that stuff and had not been disappointed. It sounds to me that this author should be more of an educator than a science fiction writer.

- His world certainly set the standard for what is the internet today. I cannot deny that the book set precedent for almost every MMO that's out there. He wrote this before that stuff existed and I have to give him credit for having a mass published book released before the internet took over.

Unfortunately, I still didn't like this book and I hated Diamond Age. I'm not very interested in reading any more books from this author.

I listened to this book on audible and then bought the paperback for my husband. Others have criticized the writing mechanics and plot issues, but the truth is, I found this book entertaining enough that I didn't notice (and don't care to notice) any lapses. Stephenson is inventive, his characters are flamboyant and engaging, and the premises are interesting. That's good enough for me.

If you've had any involvement in the online world Second Life, you would probably want to read this book... It has as much to do with the invention of Second Life, as the original Star Trek series has to do with the invention of cell phones.
That said, this is probably a glimpse of our future, or possibly that of our children.

My first read by Neal Stephenson was a delight. There is magic here! I became a huge fan of the author with this book and went on to explore many more of his books. Build a world, make it come alive and take the reader to fascinating places in superlative ways. You're going to love this book!

review_headline: I read this book in about 24 hours
review_body:
Great imagery, great imagination, and some excellent futuristic concepts.

People who write about future technology take tips from this guy.

It's because he's so deep with history-as-metaphor, and idea-as-consumption.

He has an excellent meta-philosophical premise, that ideas should lie behind his work,

but that the work must remain fundamentally superficial.

Even so, it is not a superficial book. It is an excellent book.

This is a classic that belongs on anyone's bookshelf.

Stephenson is a realist about mystique, and really has (in this book, at least)

some concept of the future.

Imaginative and a fast read. As with other books (of this type), this shows a man living in a dull storage unit by day with an exciting avatar life at night. What is interesting is the book was written in 2000, and is very current in 2013.
This is a good place to start if you're looking to try Stephenson, Cyberpunk, or just an awesomely antisocial weekend.

Snowcrash is a little hard to follow sometimes, otherwise it immerses you in the world pretty fantastically. The attention to detail and the manor in which it's presented to you makes it quite unique and gripping. Welcome to the world of Hero Protagonist, we hope you enjoy your stay.

review_headline: Nerdy, Speculative, Action Thriller with a Great Sense of Humor.
review_body:
\\"Snow Crash\\" was Neal Stephenson's breakthrough novel, published back in 1992. It was amazingly prescient for something written before commercial internet and near-universal access, and it still doesn't feel outdated 20 years later. The story takes place in the United States of the near future. The US government isn't what it used to be. It's politically impotent but employs a lot of people doing private contracting. Where there were once states and cities, now there are privately governed franchises along various cultural and ethnic themes. Our hero and protagonist is appropriately named Hiro Protagonist, former hacker, security guard, high-speed pizza delivery man, concert promoter, stringer for the Central Intelligence Corporation (CIC), and greatest sword-fighter in the world. Hiro is currently in the information business. He collects info and sells it to the CIC.

Hiro is joined by a 15-year-old Kourier named \\"YT\\". She is one of many young skateboarding phenoms who work for delivery services, zooming between franchises, filling the shoes that the postal service used to occupy. When YT agrees to share information with Hiro, she couldn't imagine what she's getting into. Neither could Hiro, when he sees the avatar of his former colleague Da5id get fried in the Metaverse, a virtual world, after Da5id experiments with a new virtual street drug called \\"snow crash.\\" This somehow scrambled his brain in the real world too, where Da5id is found in a vegetative state, babbling gibberish. It is another former programming colleague and Hiro's ex-lover, Juanita Marquez, who has a theory as to the cause: The ancient Sumerian nam-shub of Enki was a neurolinguistic virus, and someone intends to unleash it again.

I always enjoy Neal Stephenson's wry humor. He doesn't lament the loss of the old world order in \\"Snow Crash\\"; he makes fun of the new order. In some ways, the novel is a product of its time: the early internet, the beginnings of the skateboarding craze, and all of the televangelists that were on television and in the news back then. \\"Snow Crash\\"'s villain is a reverend with a media empire. This book popularized the term \\"avatar\\" and foresaw a time when humans interacted in a virtual reality. I didn't enjoy the speeches about Sumerian mythology as much as I usually enjoy Stephenson's tangents. But \\"Snow Crash\\" is basically an action novel, in spite of its characteristic literacy, with many fight scenes and characters who are very mobile and frequently armed. It's a nerdy, speculative, action thriller. Typical of a Stephenson novel, it's long but reads quickly.raze, and all of the televangelists that were on television and in the news back then. \\"Snow Crash\\"'s villain is a reverend with a media empire. This book popularized the term \\"avatar\\" and foresaw a time when humans interacted in a virtual reality. I didn't enjoy the speeches about Sumerian mythology as much as I usually enjoy Stephenson's tangents. But \\"Snow Crash\\" is basically an action novel, in spite of its characteristic literacy, with many fight scenes and characters who are very mobile and frequently armed. It's a nerdy, speculative, action thriller. Typical of a Stephenson novel, it's long but reads quickly.

review_headline: My favorite SciFi book of all time.
review_body:
I love this book. It is my favorite science fiction book.
The first chapter is a short story on its own and it is hysterical.
I worked for the busiest dominoe's pizza in the USA in the 1980's so the
first chapter makes me laugh. From there it unfolds into several stories
and characters.

It is near future science fiction. Some of his ideas
will come to pass. I imagine 100 years from now, anyone
who reads it will think it is a history book.

I often tell the part about how the main character is
proud of himself in buying virtual real estate.

review_headline: I will be buying more Stephenson.
review_body: This book was fantastic! I bought this book based on a review I had seen for "ready player one" by Ernest Cline. This is the first Neal Stephenson but I will buy more.

I listened to the audiobook narrated by Jonathan Davis, via Audible, which was a terrific narration.  This was my first jump back into cyberpunk after reading everything that Gibson has created.  I was pretty impressed.  Snow Crash grabs you quickly and introduces you to a future that amazingly enough, was created by Stephenson back in 1991 that still seems plausible today.  The book moves well until the end of the novel, where Stephenson rushes through to tie in all the plot lines together and creates a gigantic mess in the process, complete with an unbelievable deus ex machina, which leaves the reader startled and confused.  This seems to be a hallmark of some of his other novels.
Stephenson at his best in my opinion. Great imagery, great plot, wonderful characters. The end was a little bit of a let down, but not much.

In my opinion, this book is very well-written, first and foremost. I also love that this book was written by the author in the late eighties and he was able to foresee the whole internet thing. really a mark of a genius. This is mandatory if you're into the whole cyberpunk universe.
Don't know how he does it but Stephenson imagines detailed worlds of reality and technology that are amazing.  Highly recommend.

SNOW CRASH
The most startling aspect of SNOW CRASH isn't is frighteningly, realized, satirical-yet-possibly neo-dystopian future. It isn't the dizzyingly complex connections STEPHENSON makes between technology, binary codes, religion, viruses, the fall of man, the origin of myth, the disappearance of cuneiform, and convenient connects between its marginalized characters. It most startling fact is that this was written in 1992 and is mind blowingly prescient. STEPHENSON fully realizes an America in which the U.S. government is marginalized and corporate franchises and \\"Burbclaves,\\" that act as independent city states, are the only bastion of order in a world of poverty, chaos, disorder, as well as fantastic technology. Its a bleak future, but there is some order, thusly a Neo-Dystopia. As the story unfolds you even realize that these corporate entities are benevolent, when it suits their own ends. This book, especially the first third is the very definition of good cyberpunk. STEPHENSON's intent was more parody than a cyberpunk opus, but he created one anyway.
